title: Daniel Craig jets to New York as filming wraps on No Time To Die
text:
Filming wrapped for his final outing as James Bond on Friday.

And Daniel Craig looked happy and relaxed after waving goodbye to his 007 alter-ego as he arrived at JFK Airport in New York on Monday.

The actor, 51, cut a cheery figure as he strolled through the arrivals terminal, wearing a cosy black cardigan, grey trousers and a flat cap.

Bye bye, Bond: Daniel Craig looked happy and relaxed after waving goodbye to his 007 alter-ego as he arrived at JFK Airport in New York on Monday

The Bond star carried his belongings in numerous bags and kept comfortable in a pair of dark, lace-up trainers.

Filming officially wrapped for the much-anticipated 25th installment on Friday after production was marred by numerous issues.

They included the departure of original director Danny Boyle in a row over killing off Bond, an explosion at Pinewood studios, and Daniel requiring an operation after falling on set and tweaking his ankle ligaments.

This weekend, it was reported Daniel's final outing as 007 will see the character tie the knot with Madeleine Swann, played by Léa Seydoux.

Winding down: The actor, 51, cut a cheery figure as he strolled through the arrivals terminal, wearing a cosy black cardigan, grey trousers and a flat cap

A source speaking to The Mirror claimed the film will see Bond not only get married, but also that Madeleine will keep her maiden name in a bid to make the story 'move into the 21st century.'

They explained that a scene sees Daniel Craig say in character: 'Morning, Mrs Bond.'

But she will quip back: 'Don't you mean Ms Swann?'

The source went on to add: 'After Madeleine's response Bond looks at her in an admiring way. It's why he married her. She, like him, is tough and independent. The daughter of a gangster.'

Settling down: This weekend, it was reported Daniel's final outing as 007 will see the character tie the knot with Madeleine Swann, played by Léa Seydoux, 34 (pictured last month)

It was also revealed on Monday that when the Queen agreed to feature alongside Bond at the 2012 Olympic opening ceremony, she insisted that she be allowed to say, 'Good evening, Mr Bond'.

Angela Kelly, the Queen's dresser of 25 years, tells how she was called to a meeting with Boyle and private secretary Edward Young to discuss the idea in 2011.

'I asked him and Edward to give me five minutes so that I could ask the Queen,' she said.

'I remember the look of shock on Danny's face that I would be asking Her Majesty straight away, but there's no point in waiting around with these things: If she said no, that would be the end of it.

Star quality: When the Queen agreed to feature alongside Bond at the 2012 Olympic opening ceremony (pictured), she insisted that she be allowed to say, 'Good evening, Mr Bond'

'I ran upstairs and luckily the Queen was free. She was very amused by the idea and agreed immediately.

I asked if she would like a speaking part. Without hesitation, Her Majesty replied, "Of course I must say something. After all, he is coming to rescue me".

'I asked whether she would like to say, "Good evening, James" or "Good evening, Mr Bond" and she chose the latter, knowing the Bond films.

'Within minutes, I was back in Edward's office delivering the good news to Danny – I think he almost fell off his chair when I said that the Queen's only stipulation was that she could deliver that iconic line.'

End of an era: The news comes after 007's Twitter account shared a sweet snap of Daniel posing in his Bond dinner suit with director Cary Joji Fukunaga

The news comes after 007's Twitter account shared a sweet snap of Daniel posing in his Bond dinner suit with director Cary Joji Fukunaga, with the caption: 'That's a wrap on #NoTimeToDie See you in cinemas April 2020.'

In the snap, a smiling Daniel wears a padded jacket over his suit and holds onto a clapperboard marked with the final day of production - October 25.

Three different endings were reportedly filmed so as to avoid plot details being leaked.

Director Cary, 42, - who took over the project from Danny Boyle - is said to be the only one who knows which of the three finales will make the final cut.

The film is co-written by Phoebe Waller-Bridge, who wrote and starred in the hugely popular Fleabag.

The movie's UK release date is April 3, 2020, and it opens in US cinemas on April 8, 2020
